THE NEWS LETTER
VOL. XV, NO. 18.

BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 13, 1911.

HOPKINS WINS INDOOR GAMES

BOARD CREATES NEW OFFICE.

LACROSSE MEN GOING FINE.

Speedy Black and Blue Sprinters Pile
Up Greatest Number of Points in
the Biggest Games Ever Held
in Baltimore-- Horrax's
Work a Feature.

Managers of All Teams to Be Directly
Responsible to Holmes—A Great
Advance in University
Athletics.

Captain Hulburt Makes a Statement as
to the Condition of the Team—Outdoor Practice in Three Weeks.

\gainst the best athletes of .\ faryland, Pennsylvania and Virginia,
the Johns Hopkins track team
scored a notable victory last Saturday night by winning first place in
the Johns Hopkins Fifth Regiment
indoor games. Horrax was the
star performer for the Black and
Blue. He captured first place
in both the running high jump
and the hundred-yard hurdles.
This netted to points for Hopkins. Ben Tappan contributed
6 more by winning the pole vault
and third place in the hurdles. The
other Hopkins' medal winners were
Dingan. Lee and Wagner. Dingan
placed second in the shot put, and
Lee and Wagner were third in the
mile run and hundred-yard dash
Hopkins had 21
respectively.
"points to its credit, and Virginia and
Tome were the next highest point
winners, with 14 each.
Horrax had to clear the bar at
5 feet ii inches to win the high
jump, as two of his competitors
with their handicap were credited
with 5 feet 10 inches. lie succeeded
in doing so after several failures,
and was heartily applauded. In the
hurdles he broke the tape without
being ,pushed very hard by any contestants. Tappan's handicap of two
feet was ample to win first place for
him in the pole vault.
Tressider, the Canadian five-mile
champion, won his special relay
race from the three local milers
without appearing to half try.
Only in the last two laps did he
male any visible effort. His stride
was not particularly long, but it
•was as regular as clock work.
Bacon, Brigham and Lee, the medal
winners in the mile open, could
have given Tressider a much harder,/
race, and would undoubtedly have
beaten him.
Relay races were the feature of
the program. The last event was a
two-mile relay between the University of Pennsylvania and the Carlisle Indians. The Quakers more
than avenged last year's defeat, as
they completely lapped the Redskins.
The most exciting relay was between Country School and Marstons. The two teams fought for
the lead during the whole race, and
finished so close that the judges
were unable to pick the winner. A
coin was tossed for the medals, and
Country School won.

At a meeting of the Athletic
Board on Monday night an action
was taken which is a radical departure from the policy pursued
hitherto with respect to the management of the various athletic teams.
John M. Holmes was elected graduate manager of all teams for next
year. The reasons for this step
were several ; but in the main it is
because all branches of athletics,
especially football, have attained
such large proportions here at Hopkins that it is advisable to have a
man whose sole business is to look
after the teams.
The duty of the graduate manager will be to help, advise, and
assist, in any way possible, the undergraduate manager. Each manager will be responsible to him directly, and he in turn will be responsible to the Athletic Board.
All expenditures will be made
either by him or through him, and
the managers will be required to
consult him before taking any steps
on their own responsibility.
This arrangement will give the
Board more leeway. In case the
manager of a team proves incompetent, the athletic authorities can
ask for his resignation and have the
graduate manager continue with the
team for the rest of the season.
The purpose of the new arrangement is not to take any power away
from the students nor to dispense
with the undergraduate manager.
The only difference is that the student manager will not have such .a
vast amount of work and his responsibility will be practically nothing; and yet he will have all the
honor attendant upon the position.
The effect of this arrangement
in actual operation will be eagerly
watched by everyone. But there is
no doubt that everything will go
off in fine style with such a man
at the helm as John M. Holmes.
A certain college president, a
clergyman, who was addressing students in chapel at the beginning of
the year, observed that the freshman class was the largest in the
history of the college. Without
pause, the good man turned and
read for the lesson of the day, the
third Psalm—"Lord how are they
increased that trouble me."
• The date of the senior banquet
has been changed from Tuesday,
February 21, to Thursday,'February 23.

Lacrosse practice is in full swing,
the candidates are working consistently and faithfully. In about two or
three weeks the squad will be out of
doors on the Homewood green.
The intervening, time is rather dull
and uninteresting for the players,
for the novelty has worn off and
hard work is the rule. Moreover,
the "cage" lends itself very readily
to hard knocks, but as yet nobody
has received more serious damage than cuts and bruises. In spite
of this the squad is working with a
snap and vim which augurs well
for future championship. The defense and attack handle each other
most energetically, trying to make
up in ginger what they lack in
other respects.
Coach Raleigh and his assistants,
Frank and Lowndes,are now devoting most of their energies toward
the building up and developing of
the mid-field attack. This is the most
difficult thing in all lacrosse; that
is, to get the ball started in the
mid-field. New combinations are
being tried, using Wolfe, Gail,
Easter, Paulus, Bridgman, and Gillet, and new tricks and plays are
being taught at every practice.
Even Bill Schmeisser has been seen
at the practices quite often, lately.
Tappan and Kline will be welcome
additions to the squad as midfielders, and will report about
March 1. Just at present the midfield attack is not showing much
improvement, but that is the way it
usually happens. The mid-field
attack goes its own way, plays its
own game according to As own
sweet will, in spite of all the coaches
can do; then one bright day it
wakes up and for the rest of the
season plays real lacrosse as it was
taught. This day has not arrived
yet, but when it does the sparks will
fly and the goals will go in.
Not much attention is being paid
by the coaches to the close defense
and the close attack, because very
little can be done forjhese positions
until the out door practice begins.
Goal is well cared for by Sears and
Sutton. These are both good men,
and it is likely that both will be
seen between the posts in the
coming season.
Well, boys, keep up your spirits
and stick to the hard, daily grind,
for once we are out to Homewood
the practices become real fun, and
the work interesting. With such a
fine schedule, much glory awaits
us, and don't forget that this is to
be a Hopkins lacrosse championship year!

Hullabaloo Benefit.

On February 28, the Musical
Clubs will give a concert in McCoy
Hall for the benefit of the Hullabaloo.- The Clubs have been a
great success this year; but this
concert will surpass any of the
former ones. An elaborate programme has been planned, and new
songs and pieces are being learned
for the occasion. After the concert
there will be an informal dance.
Inasmuch as this is the largest
concert of the year, and since it
is being given to help publish the
Hullabaloo, everyone in the University should turn out in full force.
Besides, there will be plenty of
harmony and very little agony;
there will be solos, quartettes, and
choruses, and the Instrumental Club
will render selections that will make
those who trip the "light fantastic
toe" fairly tingle.
The concert will begin at 8.15.
Tickets will be on sale at Albaugh's
after February II.
Baseball Schedule.

The baseball schedule has been
completed. It is as follows:
April 8—Gallaudet, at Washington.
April 15—Harvard, at Homewood.
April 17—Pensylvania, at Homewood.
April 19—Catholic University, at
Washington.
April 22—Washington College,
at Chestertown.
April 29—Western Maryland, at
Westminster.
May 6—No game.
May 13—Delaware, at Newark.
May 20—St. Johns, at Annapolis.
The candidates are having daily
practice in the "cage" under Coach
Hooper and Captain Pieper. The
outlook, in spite of its being the
first season of baseball for some
years at Hopkins, is bright, and the
supporters of the team feel much
encouraged.

Gilman and Dr. Andrew D. White
were the two men who first urged
that the history of international arbitration, the Hague Conferences
and the growth of Internationalism
should be brought before the college students of the country. The
views of both men were first made
public at the Lake Mohonk Conference in 1905, and soon after the
movement was started. In the five
years which have elapsed, very
practical results have been attained.
We have a double interest, therefore, in the work of the International School of Peace, and should
do everything in our power to support it.

Arbitration Society.

The Arbitration Society will meet
in the Donovan Room, Wednesday
afternoon, at 5 o'clock. Several
members of the Society will speak.
The general subject to be discussed
is the fortification of the Panama
Canal.
Four colleges besides Hopkins
have entered the oratorical contest:
George Washington, St. Johns,
Washington College, and Loyola.
It is possible that Western Maryland will send a representative.
Hopkins Men Speak.

The Public Health Congress
opened on Monday, February 6.
This is one of the most important
meetings of its kind that has been
held in recent years, its object being
to enlighten the public on the right
method of living.
Hopkins men present were: Dr.
William H. Welch, who was
chairman of the opening session;
Dr. L. F. Barker, who spoke on
"The prevention of nervousness in
children and the protection of the
nervous child ;" and Dr. Adolph
Meyer, who spoke on "How and
when to get help in mental disorders."

ALBERT SHAW: Whenever we
pick up a copy of the Review of Reviews, we all of us see on the cover,
and some few of us recognize, the
name of the editor, Albert Shaw.
It is probably very, very few of us,
however, who connect that name in
any way with the Hopkins, or know
that its bearer was one of the host
of young enthusiasts who in the
early days of the University came
from some fresh-water college in the
West to pursue higher studies at
the greatest postgraduate school in
America, and went forth into the
world fortified with a doctor's degree from the Hopkins. Dr. Shaw
was a member of the University
during the two years, 1882-84, and
attending in company with Wood-row Wilson, the historical and economic seminaries, then under the
direction of Prof. Herbert B.
Adams and Dr. Richard T. Ely,
respectively. In 1884 he received
his Ph.D. degree, submitting as his
thesis a study of "Etienne Cadet
and Icaria," a book which was
brought out the same year by the
Putnams. After a few years of
journalism and study abroad, and
after refusing an offer to become
professor of political and international law at Cornell, Dr. Shaw established in 1891 the American Review of Reviews, of which he has
since been editor.
He is the author of numerous
works on economics and government, and for one of them, "Municipal Government in Great Britain," he was honored by his alma
mater in 1894 with the John Marshall Prize.

the preface to the volume before us,
when they excuse their labors on
the plea that to the true appreciation of literature, a right understanding of syntax is indispensable.

Lincoln Burr, of Cornell University,
delivered two lectures on the Venezuelan boundary dispute The
lectures were primarily for the

George Lincoln Burr was born in
Oramel, N. Y., January 30, 1857.
He graduated from Cornell with
honors in 1881. From 1834 to 1836
and in 1888 he studied in Europe
at the Universities of Liepzig
and Zurich, at the Sorbonne,
and at the Ecole des Chartes. He
received the degrees LL.D. from
the University of Wisconsin, 1904,
and Litt.D. from Western Reserv.e
University, 1905. Since 1878 he
has been librarian of the White
Library at Cornell, and instructOr,
assistant professor, and professor
of history at Cornell since 188i.
He came into prominence when he
was appointed during President
Cleveland's administration a historical expert to the Venezuela Boundary Commission, 1896-7. Professor Burr has been an editor of the
American Historical Review since

(THE NEWS-LETTER is always glad to
publish letters of reasonable length
upon topics of interest in the University
circles. Alumni especially are urged to
make use of this column.)
February 6. 1911.
THE NEWS-LETTER.
Every Hopkins man, alumnus,
graduate, medic, or undergraduate,
should appreciate the splendid forward movement made by the undergraduate editorial staff of Tini
NEWS-LETTER this year, and give
it his financial support. THE
NEWS-LETTER has become a more
representative University publication than it ever has been. The
writer, however, would like to suggest a way of placing it upon a
sounder basis than now exists, so
that it may become equal to the best
of college and university papers.
In the first place, the editorial
staff should be chosen exclusively
by compet.tion, and not by vote of
a close corporation. This is the
method adopted at other institutions. The editor should keep all
copy and all articles contributed, so
that at the end of the year an examining board composed, for instance,
of the editor, a professor from the
English department, and a representative of the Sun, News, or
American could judge the merits of
each competitor's case, and thus appoint a new board.
This system will make a place on
the staff a greater honor than it
is at present, though, no doubt,
there is unorganized competition for
some of the positions at the present
time. In other colleges and universties it is practically unheard of
for a member of the publication
board to resign in the midst of the
It should be the same at
year.
Hopkins. One way by which the
editor can be compensated for the
loss of his time is to award him
credits on his university hours, provided he publishes a satisfactory
paper. Such could be made the
case here by faculty action. and undoubtedly it will come.
As far as the management of the
paper is concerned, it too, should be
placed in the hands of the whole
student body. A change in this
regard, however, could very well
afford to go over until the suggested
reforms in the editorial staff have
been carried out.
Trusting that Tim NEWS-LETTER
will continue to grow in value to/
the University, and that every
means to further that end will be
adopted by the undergraduate body,
which, alone, can publish it, these
ideas are offered by,
Yours very truly,
FRANK T. STOCKTON.

The freshmangv unasium contest
has reached a most exciting climax.
Both the Whites and Blues hate 'to
think what may happen at the next
meeting. This is the way things
stand : the sides are only seven
points apart and but two events are
left. It is evident that these events,
25-yard dash and the relay race,
will decide the contest. It looks as
though Captain White (Whites)
and Riley (Blues) would fight it
out for first place. It is not so easy
to forcast the winners of the relay,
as each man must run one lap and
the outcome will be uncertain up
to the last.
Last Monday the potato race

occupied the whole "gym" period.

Steuart White crossed the finish
line first, but as he did so his dumbbells, which he had carefully
placed in his circle, slowly, gracefully, and tantalizingly rolled out
of the ring. With White disqualified, his team got but one place out
of the six. Wells (Blues) was
first, and Riley (Blues) second.

THE NEWS LETTER
VOL. XV, NO. 18.

BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 13, 1911.

HOPKINS WINS INDOOR GAMES

BOARD CREATES NEW OFFICE.

LACROSSE MEN GOING FINE.

Speedy Black and Blue Sprinters Pile
Up Greatest Number of Points in
the Biggest Games Ever Held
in Baltimore-- Horrax's
Work a Feature.

Managers of All Teams to Be Directly
Responsible to Holmes—A Great
Advance in University
Athletics.

Captain Hulburt Makes a Statement as
to the Condition of the Team—Outdoor Practice in Three Weeks.

\gainst the best athletes of .\ faryland, Pennsylvania and Virginia,
the Johns Hopkins track team
scored a notable victory last Saturday night by winning first place in
the Johns Hopkins Fifth Regiment
indoor games. Horrax was the
star performer for the Black and
Blue. He captured first place
in both the running high jump
and the hundred-yard hurdles.
This netted to points for Hopkins. Ben Tappan contributed
6 more by winning the pole vault
and third place in the hurdles. The
other Hopkins' medal winners were
Dingan. Lee and Wagner. Dingan
placed second in the shot put, and
Lee and Wagner were third in the
mile run and hundred-yard dash
Hopkins had 21
respectively.
"points to its credit, and Virginia and
Tome were the next highest point
winners, with 14 each.
Horrax had to clear the bar at
5 feet ii inches to win the high
jump, as two of his competitors
with their handicap were credited
with 5 feet 10 inches. lie succeeded
in doing so after several failures,
and was heartily applauded. In the
hurdles he broke the tape without
being ,pushed very hard by any contestants. Tappan's handicap of two
feet was ample to win first place for
him in the pole vault.
Tressider, the Canadian five-mile
champion, won his special relay
race from the three local milers
without appearing to half try.
Only in the last two laps did he
male any visible effort. His stride
was not particularly long, but it
•was as regular as clock work.
Bacon, Brigham and Lee, the medal
winners in the mile open, could
have given Tressider a much harder,/
race, and would undoubtedly have
beaten him.
Relay races were the feature of
the program. The last event was a
two-mile relay between the University of Pennsylvania and the Carlisle Indians. The Quakers more
than avenged last year's defeat, as
they completely lapped the Redskins.
The most exciting relay was between Country School and Marstons. The two teams fought for
the lead during the whole race, and
finished so close that the judges
were unable to pick the winner. A
coin was tossed for the medals, and
Country School won.

At a meeting of the Athletic
Board on Monday night an action
was taken which is a radical departure from the policy pursued
hitherto with respect to the management of the various athletic teams.
John M. Holmes was elected graduate manager of all teams for next
year. The reasons for this step
were several ; but in the main it is
because all branches of athletics,
especially football, have attained
such large proportions here at Hopkins that it is advisable to have a
man whose sole business is to look
after the teams.
The duty of the graduate manager will be to help, advise, and
assist, in any way possible, the undergraduate manager. Each manager will be responsible to him directly, and he in turn will be responsible to the Athletic Board.
All expenditures will be made
either by him or through him, and
the managers will be required to
consult him before taking any steps
on their own responsibility.
This arrangement will give the
Board more leeway. In case the
manager of a team proves incompetent, the athletic authorities can
ask for his resignation and have the
graduate manager continue with the
team for the rest of the season.
The purpose of the new arrangement is not to take any power away
from the students nor to dispense
with the undergraduate manager.
The only difference is that the student manager will not have such .a
vast amount of work and his responsibility will be practically nothing; and yet he will have all the
honor attendant upon the position.
The effect of this arrangement
in actual operation will be eagerly
watched by everyone. But there is
no doubt that everything will go
off in fine style with such a man
at the helm as John M. Holmes.
A certain college president, a
clergyman, who was addressing students in chapel at the beginning of
the year, observed that the freshman class was the largest in the
history of the college. Without
pause, the good man turned and
read for the lesson of the day, the
third Psalm—"Lord how are they
increased that trouble me."
• The date of the senior banquet
has been changed from Tuesday,
February 21, to Thursday,'February 23.

Lacrosse practice is in full swing,
the candidates are working consistently and faithfully. In about two or
three weeks the squad will be out of
doors on the Homewood green.
The intervening, time is rather dull
and uninteresting for the players,
for the novelty has worn off and
hard work is the rule. Moreover,
the "cage" lends itself very readily
to hard knocks, but as yet nobody
has received more serious damage than cuts and bruises. In spite
of this the squad is working with a
snap and vim which augurs well
for future championship. The defense and attack handle each other
most energetically, trying to make
up in ginger what they lack in
other respects.
Coach Raleigh and his assistants,
Frank and Lowndes,are now devoting most of their energies toward
the building up and developing of
the mid-field attack. This is the most
difficult thing in all lacrosse; that
is, to get the ball started in the
mid-field. New combinations are
being tried, using Wolfe, Gail,
Easter, Paulus, Bridgman, and Gillet, and new tricks and plays are
being taught at every practice.
Even Bill Schmeisser has been seen
at the practices quite often, lately.
Tappan and Kline will be welcome
additions to the squad as midfielders, and will report about
March 1. Just at present the midfield attack is not showing much
improvement, but that is the way it
usually happens. The mid-field
attack goes its own way, plays its
own game according to As own
sweet will, in spite of all the coaches
can do; then one bright day it
wakes up and for the rest of the
season plays real lacrosse as it was
taught. This day has not arrived
yet, but when it does the sparks will
fly and the goals will go in.
Not much attention is being paid
by the coaches to the close defense
and the close attack, because very
little can be done forjhese positions
until the out door practice begins.
Goal is well cared for by Sears and
Sutton. These are both good men,
and it is likely that both will be
seen between the posts in the
coming season.
Well, boys, keep up your spirits
and stick to the hard, daily grind,
for once we are out to Homewood
the practices become real fun, and
the work interesting. With such a
fine schedule, much glory awaits
us, and don't forget that this is to
be a Hopkins lacrosse championship year!

Hullabaloo Benefit.

On February 28, the Musical
Clubs will give a concert in McCoy
Hall for the benefit of the Hullabaloo.- The Clubs have been a
great success this year; but this
concert will surpass any of the
former ones. An elaborate programme has been planned, and new
songs and pieces are being learned
for the occasion. After the concert
there will be an informal dance.
Inasmuch as this is the largest
concert of the year, and since it
is being given to help publish the
Hullabaloo, everyone in the University should turn out in full force.
Besides, there will be plenty of
harmony and very little agony;
there will be solos, quartettes, and
choruses, and the Instrumental Club
will render selections that will make
those who trip the "light fantastic
toe" fairly tingle.
The concert will begin at 8.15.
Tickets will be on sale at Albaugh's
after February II.
Baseball Schedule.

The baseball schedule has been
completed. It is as follows:
April 8—Gallaudet, at Washington.
April 15—Harvard, at Homewood.
April 17—Pensylvania, at Homewood.
April 19—Catholic University, at
Washington.
April 22—Washington College,
at Chestertown.
April 29—Western Maryland, at
Westminster.
May 6—No game.
May 13—Delaware, at Newark.
May 20—St. Johns, at Annapolis.
The candidates are having daily
practice in the "cage" under Coach
Hooper and Captain Pieper. The
outlook, in spite of its being the
first season of baseball for some
years at Hopkins, is bright, and the
supporters of the team feel much
encouraged.

The Arbitration Society will meet
in the Donovan Room, Wednesday
afternoon, at 5 o'clock. Several
members of the Society will speak.
The general subject to be discussed
is the fortification of the Panama
Canal.
Four colleges besides Hopkins
have entered the oratorical contest:
George Washington, St. Johns,
Washington College, and Loyola.
It is possible that Western Maryland will send a representative.
Hopkins Men Speak.

The Public Health Congress
opened on Monday, February 6.
This is one of the most important
meetings of its kind that has been
held in recent years, its object being
to enlighten the public on the right
method of living.
Hopkins men present were: Dr.
William H. Welch, who was
chairman of the opening session;
Dr. L. F. Barker, who spoke on
"The prevention of nervousness in
children and the protection of the
nervous child ;" and Dr. Adolph
Meyer, who spoke on "How and
when to get help in mental disorders."

ALBERT SHAW: Whenever we
pick up a copy of the Review of Reviews, we all of us see on the cover,
and some few of us recognize, the
name of the editor, Albert Shaw.
It is probably very, very few of us,
however, who connect that name in
any way with the Hopkins, or know
that its bearer was one of the host
of young enthusiasts who in the
early days of the University came
from some fresh-water college in the
West to pursue higher studies at
the greatest postgraduate school in
America, and went forth into the
world fortified with a doctor's degree from the Hopkins. Dr. Shaw
was a member of the University
during the two years, 1882-84, and
attending in company with Wood-row Wilson, the historical and economic seminaries, then under the
direction of Prof. Herbert B.
Adams and Dr. Richard T. Ely,
respectively. In 1884 he received
his Ph.D. degree, submitting as his
thesis a study of "Etienne Cadet
and Icaria," a book which was
brought out the same year by the
Putnams. After a few years of
journalism and study abroad, and
after refusing an offer to become
professor of political and international law at Cornell, Dr. Shaw established in 1891 the American Review of Reviews, of which he has
since been editor.
He is the author of numerous
works on economics and government, and for one of them, "Municipal Government in Great Britain," he was honored by his alma
mater in 1894 with the John Marshall Prize.

.Syntax of Classical Greekfrom Homer
to Demosthenes; second part. By Basil
Lanneau Gildersleeve, with the cooperation of Chas. Wm. Emil Miller of
the Johns Hopkins University. American Book Company, 1911.

After an interval of eleven years
since the publication of its predecessor, the second part of Gildersleeve
and Miller's Syntax has at last appeared. The volumes are fragments of a series of works on Greek
grammar, which was to follow, on
a .more elaborate scale, the lines
which had proved so successful in
Prof. Gildersleeve's famous Latin
Grammar. The idea of the series
was abandoned, but it has been
productive of the two volumes already issued, and the concluding
words of Prof. Gildersleeve's preface lead us to hope that more will
be forthcoming. In these days
when so many philologists are prone
to the view that literature exists
solely for the illustration of syntax, we heartily applaud the attitude which the authors assume in
the preface to the volume before us,
when they excuse their labors on
the plea that to the true appreciation of literature, a right understanding of syntax is indispensable.
J. S. D.

Dr. Burr Lectures.

On Thursday and Friday, February 9 and Jo, Professor George
Lincoln Burr, of Cornell University,
delivered two lectures on the Venezuelan boundary dispute The
lectures were primarily for the
graduate students, but were open to
all students of the Univers:ty.
George Lincoln Burr was born in
Oramel, N. Y., January 30, 1857.
He graduated from Cornell with
honors in 1881. From 1834 to 1836
and in 1888 he studied in Europe
at the Universities of Liepzig
and Zurich, at the Sorbonne,
and at the Ecole des Chartes. He
received the degrees LL.D. from
the University of Wisconsin, 1904,
and Litt.D. from Western Reserv.e
University, 1905. Since 1878 he
has been librarian of the White
Library at Cornell, and instructOr,
assistant professor, and professor
of history at Cornell since 188i.
He came into prominence when he
was appointed during President
Cleveland's administration a historical expert to the Venezuela Boundary Commission, 1896-7. Professor Burr has been an editor of the
American Historical Review since
1905.

(THE NEWS-LETTER is always glad to
publish letters of reasonable length
upon topics of interest in the University
circles. Alumni especially are urged to
make use of this column.)
February 6. 1911.
THE NEWS-LETTER.
Every Hopkins man, alumnus,
graduate, medic, or undergraduate,
should appreciate the splendid forward movement made by the undergraduate editorial staff of Tini
NEWS-LETTER this year, and give
it his financial support. THE
NEWS-LETTER has become a more
representative University publication than it ever has been. The
writer, however, would like to suggest a way of placing it upon a
sounder basis than now exists, so
that it may become equal to the best
of college and university papers.
In the first place, the editorial
staff should be chosen exclusively
by compet.tion, and not by vote of
a close corporation. This is the
method adopted at other institutions. The editor should keep all
copy and all articles contributed, so
that at the end of the year an examining board composed, for instance,
of the editor, a professor from the
English department, and a representative of the Sun, News, or
American could judge the merits of
each competitor's case, and thus appoint a new board.
This system will make a place on
the staff a greater honor than it
is at present, though, no doubt,
there is unorganized competition for
some of the positions at the present
time. In other colleges and universties it is practically unheard of
for a member of the publication
board to resign in the midst of the
It should be the same at
year.
Hopkins. One way by which the
editor can be compensated for the
loss of his time is to award him
credits on his university hours, provided he publishes a satisfactory
paper. Such could be made the
case here by faculty action. and undoubtedly it will come.
As far as the management of the
paper is concerned, it too, should be
placed in the hands of the whole
student body. A change in this
regard, however, could very well
afford to go over until the suggested
reforms in the editorial staff have
been carried out.
Trusting that Tim NEWS-LETTER
will continue to grow in value to/
the University, and that every
means to further that end will be
adopted by the undergraduate body,
which, alone, can publish it, these
ideas are offered by,
Yours very truly,
FRANK T. STOCKTON.

Gymnasium Contest.

The freshmangv unasium contest
has reached a most exciting climax.
Both the Whites and Blues hate 'to
think what may happen at the next
meeting. This is the way things
stand : the sides are only seven
points apart and but two events are
left. It is evident that these events,
25-yard dash and the relay race,
will decide the contest. It looks as
though Captain White (Whites)
and Riley (Blues) would fight it
out for first place. It is not so easy
to forcast the winners of the relay,
as each man must run one lap and
the outcome will be uncertain up
to the last.
Last Monday the potato race
(dumb-bells instead of potatoes)
occupied the whole "gym" period.
When the winners of the heats met,
Steuart White crossed the finish
line first, but as he did so his dumbbells, which he had carefully
placed in his circle, slowly, gracefully, and tantalizingly rolled out
of the ring. With White disqualified, his team got but one place out
of the six. Wells (Blues) was
first, and Riley (Blues) second.
